Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: Church of the Gesù, Rome, Italy
Baroque_and_Rococo.dimensions: Nave vault: approximately 17 m × 36 m (56 ft × 118 ft)
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of Baroque illusionism, this fresco exemplifies the Counter-Reformation's use of dramatic art to inspire faith and awe, and is celebrated for its dynamic composition and integration of painting and sculpture.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane, also known as San Carlino, is a small Roman Catholic church in Rome, Italy, designed by the architect Francesco Borromini. It is celebrated as a masterpiece of Baroque architecture, notable for its innovative use of complex geometry, undulating walls, and an oval dome. The church was Borromini's first independent commission and was built for the Spanish Trinitarians on the Quirinal Hill. Its dynamic façade and interior spatial complexity exemplify the Baroque emphasis on movement, drama, and the interplay of light and shadow.
Baroque_and_Rococo.dimensions: Church plan: approx. 20 m × 12 m (65 ft × 39 ft); Dome height: approx. 20 m (65 ft)
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A landmark of Baroque architecture, San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane is renowned for Borromini's daring spatial innovations and mastery of complex forms, influencing generations of architects and marking a turning point in the history of Western architecture.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane (interior)
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The interior of San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane, known as San Carlino, is a masterpiece of Baroque architecture designed by Francesco Borromini. Characterized by its undulating walls, innovative use of light, and complex geometrical forms, the church's interior exemplifies Borromini's radical approach to space and structure. The oval dome, intricate stucco work, and dynamic interplay of convex and concave surfaces create a sense of movement and spiritual transcendence. Built for the Spanish Trinitarian order, the church was Borromini's first independent commission and remains a landmark of Roman Baroque architecture.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane, Via del Quirinale 23, Rome, Italy
Baroque_and_Rococo.dimensions: Interior length approx. 20.4 m; width approx. 12 m; dome height approx. 20 m
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A revolutionary example of Baroque architecture, San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane's interior is celebrated for its innovative spatial design, masterful manipulation of light, and the inventive use of geometry, making it one of the most influential church interiors of the 17th century.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Palace of Versailles
Baroque_and_Rococo.artist: Louis Le Vau, Jules Hardouin-Mansart, André Le Nôtre (gardens), Charles Le Brun (interiors)
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Palace of Versailles is a monumental royal residence commissioned by King Louis XIV, located in Versailles, about 18 kilometres west of Paris, France. Renowned for its opulent architecture, lavish gardens, and significant role in French history, it exemplifies the grandeur of French Baroque style.
Baroque_and_Rococo.medium: Stone, marble, gilded wood, glass, and ornamental gardens
Baroque_and_Rococo.dimensions: Palace: approximately 67,000 m² (720,000 sq ft); Gardens: over 800 hectares (2,000 acres)
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of French Baroque architecture and landscape design, the Palace of Versailles symbolized the absolute power of the French monarchy and set the standard for royal courts across Europe. It was the principal royal residence of France from 1682 until the French Revolution and is now a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Hall of Mirrors
Baroque_and_Rococo.artist: Jules Hardouin-Mansart (architect), Charles Le Brun (interior decoration)
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Hall of Mirrors (Galerie des Glaces) is a grand Baroque gallery in the Palace of Versailles, France. Designed by architect Jules Hardouin-Mansart and decorated by Charles Le Brun, it features 357 mirrors reflecting the gardens through seventeen arched windows. The hall was conceived to glorify the reign of Louis XIV and to impress visitors with the king's wealth and power. It has hosted many significant historical events, including the signing of the Treaty of Versailles in 1919.
Baroque_and_Rococo.medium: Architecture with marble, glass mirrors, gilded bronze, and painted ceilings
Baroque_and_Rococo.dimensions: Length: 73 m (240 ft); Width: 10.5 m (34 ft); Height: 12.3 m (40 ft)
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of Baroque architecture and interior design, the Hall of Mirrors symbolizes the absolute monarchy of Louis XIV and has been the site of major historical events, including the signing of the Treaty of Versailles.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Et in Arcadia Ego
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Et in Arcadia Ego is a painting by Nicolas Poussin, created between 1637 and 1638. The work depicts a group of idealized shepherds and a woman in a classical Arcadian landscape, gathered around a tomb inscribed with the Latin phrase "Et in Arcadia ego," which is commonly interpreted as a memento mori: 'Even in Arcadia, there am I,' referring to the presence of death even in idyllic settings. The painting is celebrated for its serene composition and philosophical depth, reflecting Poussin's classical approach and interest in themes of mortality and the pastoral ideal.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of French Classicism, this painting is renowned for its profound meditation on mortality and the human condition, as well as its influence on later interpretations of the Arcadian theme in Western art.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: The Rape of the Daughters of Leucippus
Baroque_and_Rococo.artist: Peter Paul Rubens and Jan Wildens
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Rape of the Daughters of Leucippus is a monumental Baroque painting by Peter Paul Rubens, with landscape elements by Jan Wildens. It depicts the abduction of Phoebe and Hilaeira, daughters of Leucippus, by the twin brothers Castor and Pollux from Greek mythology. The dynamic composition, dramatic gestures, and sensuous forms exemplify Rubens' mastery of movement and emotion.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is a prime example of Rubens' dynamic Baroque style, celebrated for its dramatic composition, vibrant color, and sensuous depiction of mythological subjects. It also demonstrates the collaborative nature of Flemish workshops, with Jan Wildens contributing the landscape elements.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Adoration of the Shepherds
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Georges de La Tour's 'Adoration of the Shepherds' is a masterful depiction of the nativity scene, focusing on the humble shepherds gathered around the newborn Christ. The painting is renowned for its dramatic use of chiaroscuro, with the figures illuminated by a single candle, creating a sense of intimacy and spiritual reverence. La Tour's interpretation is notable for its quiet, contemplative mood and the naturalistic portrayal of the figures.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, USA
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is considered one of La Tour's masterpieces, exemplifying his unique approach to light and his influence from Caravaggio. It is celebrated for its serene atmosphere and psychological depth, marking a significant contribution to French Baroque painting.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: The Jewish Bride
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Jewish Bride is an intimate double portrait by Rembrandt, painted around 1665–1669, depicting a man and woman in a tender embrace, traditionally interpreted as a father and daughter or a married couple from the Old Testament.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: Considered one of Rembrandt's masterpieces, the painting is celebrated for its profound emotional depth, masterful use of color and light, and its sensitive portrayal of human affection.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Still Life with Oysters
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Still Life with Oysters is a masterful example of Dutch Golden Age still life painting, depicting a lavish arrangement of oysters, fruit, glassware, and luxurious objects on a table. The work showcases de Heem's virtuosity in rendering textures, reflections, and the interplay of light, symbolizing both abundance and the transience of earthly pleasures.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting exemplifies the opulent and symbolic still lifes of the Dutch Golden Age, reflecting both the wealth and the moral concerns of 17th-century society. Jan Davidsz. de Heem is celebrated for his intricate compositions and technical brilliance.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Embarkation for Cythera
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Embarkation for Cythera is a celebrated painting by French Rococo artist Jean-Antoine Watteau, depicting elegantly dressed couples preparing to depart for the mythical island of Cythera, the birthplace of Venus.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of the Rococo era, this painting established Watteau's reputation and introduced the 'fête galante' genre, capturing the spirit of romantic escapism and refined leisure.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: The Toilet of Venus
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Toilet of Venus, also known as The Rokeby Venus, is a celebrated Rococo painting by François Boucher. Commissioned by Madame de Pompadour, the influential mistress of Louis XV, the work depicts the Roman goddess Venus attended by cherubs in a sumptuous, sensual setting. The painting exemplifies Boucher's mastery of delicate color, graceful composition, and erotic elegance.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, USA
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A quintessential example of French Rococo painting, this work highlights Boucher's role as a leading artist of his time and his influence on the decorative arts and court culture of 18th-century France.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Madame de Pompadour
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: This portrait depicts Jeanne Antoinette Poisson, Marquise de Pompadour, the influential mistress and advisor of King Louis XV. Painted by François Boucher, her favored court artist, it exemplifies the elegance and refinement of the French Rococo style. Madame de Pompadour is shown surrounded by symbols of her intellect, taste, and patronage of the arts.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of Rococo portraiture, this painting not only immortalizes Madame de Pompadour's beauty and status but also reflects her role as a major patron of the arts and culture in 18th-century France.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Cupid a Captive
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Cupid a Captive is a Rococo painting by François Boucher, depicting the mythological figure Cupid bound and surrounded by a group of nymphs. The work exemplifies Boucher's mastery of sensuality, delicate color palette, and playful compositions, characteristic of the Rococo period.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: The Wallace Collection, London, United Kingdom
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A quintessential example of Rococo art, this painting showcases Boucher's skill in rendering mythological subjects with grace, eroticism, and decorative flair. It is celebrated for its lively composition and exquisite use of color.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Interior of Sant'Ignazio
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The interior of Sant'Ignazio in Rome is renowned for Andrea Pozzo's illusionistic frescoes, including the celebrated ceiling depicting the Apotheosis of Saint Ignatius. Pozzo's masterful use of perspective creates the illusion of a vast, open sky and soaring architecture, exemplifying the grandeur and theatricality of Baroque art.
Baroque_and_Rococo.dimensions: Ceiling fresco: approximately 17 m × 36 m (56 ft × 118 ft)
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterpiece of Baroque illusionism, Pozzo's frescoes in Sant'Ignazio are celebrated for their pioneering use of trompe-l'œil perspective, transforming the church's interior and influencing generations of artists and architects.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Triumph of the Name of Jesus (Ceiling of the Gesù)
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The ceiling fresco 'Triumph of the Name of Jesus' in the Church of the Gesù in Rome is a masterpiece of Baroque illusionism. Painted by Giovanni Battista Gaulli, known as Baciccio, the work covers the nave vault and depicts the radiant monogram of Christ (IHS) surrounded by a throng of angels, saints, and the damned. The fresco creates a dramatic illusion of figures spilling out of the painted architecture into the real space of the church, blurring the boundaries between the heavenly and earthly realms. This dynamic composition exemplifies the theatricality and emotional intensity of Baroque art, serving as a visual manifestation of the Counter-Reformation ideals promoted by the Jesuit order.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: Church of the Gesù, 54 Piazza del Gesù, Rome, Italy
Baroque_and_Rococo.dimensions: Nave vault: approximately 17 m × 35 m (56 ft × 115 ft)
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A seminal work of Baroque ceiling painting, renowned for its illusionistic techniques and its influence on church decoration throughout Europe. It powerfully expresses the spiritual and theatrical aims of the Counter-Reformation.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: The Banquet of Cleopatra
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Banquet of Cleopatra is a monumental painting by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo depicting the legendary banquet in which Cleopatra wagers with Mark Antony that she can host the most extravagant feast. To win, she dissolves a priceless pearl in vinegar and drinks it. The scene is set in a grand architectural setting, filled with opulent details and vibrant figures, exemplifying Tiepolo's mastery of theatrical composition and light.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne, Australia
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is considered one of Tiepolo's masterpieces and a prime example of 18th-century Venetian Rococo. It showcases his skill in grand historical narrative, theatricality, and luminous color, and was influential in the development of large-scale history painting.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Apollo and Marsyas
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Apollo and Marsyas is a dramatic Baroque painting by Spanish artist Jusepe de Ribera, depicting the mythological punishment of the satyr Marsyas by the god Apollo. The work captures the moment when Apollo flays Marsyas alive after losing a musical contest, rendered with Ribera's characteristic realism and intense emotional expression.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is a masterful example of Ribera's Baroque style, notable for its powerful depiction of suffering and its technical virtuosity. It is considered one of the most important representations of the Apollo and Marsyas myth in European art and exemplifies Ribera's influence on Neapolitan painting.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Still Life with Fruit
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Still Life with Fruit is a seminal work by Spanish painter Juan Sánchez Cotán, renowned for its austere composition and dramatic use of light and shadow. The painting features fruit and vegetables meticulously arranged on a stone ledge, exemplifying the early Spanish bodegón style.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: San Diego Museum of Art, San Diego, California, USA
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is considered a masterpiece of early Spanish still life, notable for its realism, geometric clarity, and influence on later developments in European still life painting.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: The Immaculate Conception
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Immaculate Conception is a celebrated painting by Spanish Baroque artist Bartolomé Esteban Murillo, depicting the Virgin Mary as free from original sin from the moment of her conception. The work is renowned for its ethereal depiction of Mary, surrounded by cherubs and bathed in celestial light, symbolizing her purity and grace. Murillo painted several versions of this theme, with this particular work considered one of his masterpieces.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is one of the most iconic representations of the Immaculate Conception and exemplifies Murillo's mastery of light, color, and religious iconography. It played a significant role in shaping the visual culture of Marian devotion in Spain and beyond.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: The Clubfoot
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: The Clubfoot is a 1642 oil on canvas painting by Spanish Baroque artist Jusepe de Ribera. It depicts a young boy with a physical disability, holding a note and a walking stick, rendered with empathy and realism. The painting is celebrated for its psychological depth and naturalistic detail.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: A masterful example of Baroque realism, the painting is notable for its compassionate portrayal of disability and marginalized individuals. It is considered a touchstone for understanding Ribera's focus on human dignity and his dramatic use of light and shadow.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Portrait of Pope Innocent X
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Portrait of Pope Innocent X is an oil on canvas portrait by the Spanish painter Diego Velázquez, painted during his second trip to Italy in 1650. The work is renowned for its psychological intensity and unflinching realism, capturing the shrewd and formidable character of Pope Innocent X. The pope is depicted seated in a richly upholstered chair, dressed in vivid red papal vestments, with a penetrating gaze that has fascinated viewers and influenced generations of artists.
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: Widely considered one of the greatest portraits ever painted, this work is celebrated for its psychological depth, technical mastery, and influence on later artists such as Francis Bacon.

Baroque_and_Rococo.title: Landscape with the Fall of Icarus
Baroque_and_Rococo.artist: Unknown artist after Pieter Bruegel the Elder
Baroque_and_Rococo.description: Landscape with the Fall of Icarus is a painting depicting the mythological story of Icarus, who fell into the sea after flying too close to the sun. The composition is attributed to Pieter Bruegel the Elder, but the surviving work is now generally considered an early copy by an unknown artist, based on Bruegel's lost original. The painting is notable for its innovative focus on the everyday life of peasants and farmers, relegating the dramatic fall of Icarus to a minor detail in the lower right corner. This approach reflects Bruegel's interest in human activity and the insignificance of individual tragedy in the broader context of daily life.
Baroque_and_Rococo.current_location: Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels
Baroque_and_Rococo.significance: This painting is celebrated for its innovative narrative technique, juxtaposing mythological tragedy with the indifference of everyday rural life. It is a key example of the Northern Renaissance's interest in landscape and genre painting, and has inspired numerous literary and artistic responses, including W. H. Auden's poem 'Musée des Beaux Arts.'

1800s.title: The Third of May 1808
1800s.description: The Third of May 1808, also known in Spanish as El tres de mayo de 1808 en Madrid or Los fusilamientos de la montaña del Príncipe Pío, is a painting completed in 1814 by Spanish artist Francisco Goya. The work commemorates the Spanish resistance to Napoleon's armies during the occupation of Madrid in 1808, at the beginning of the Peninsular War. It depicts the execution of Spanish rebels by French soldiers and is renowned for its emotional intensity and innovative composition. The painting, along with its companion piece The Second of May 1808, was commissioned by the provisional government of Spain after the expulsion of the French and the restoration of King Ferdinand VII.
1800s.significance: A landmark of Romantic art, The Third of May 1808 is celebrated for its powerful depiction of the horrors of war and its influence on later artists. It is considered one of the first modern paintings to portray war from the perspective of the victims, emphasizing human suffering and protest against violence.

1800s.title: Liberty Leading the People
1800s.description: Liberty Leading the People is a monumental Romantic painting by Eugène Delacroix commemorating the July Revolution of 1830 in France. The central allegorical figure, Liberty, personified as Marianne, leads a diverse group of revolutionaries over a barricade and the bodies of the fallen, holding the tricolor flag and a musket. The work is celebrated for its dynamic composition, emotional intensity, and political symbolism, encapsulating the spirit of revolution and the fight for freedom.
1800s.significance: A defining image of the Romantic era and a powerful symbol of liberty and revolution, this painting has become an enduring emblem of the French Republic and the universal struggle for freedom.

1800s.title: The Gleaners
1800s.description: The Gleaners is an oil painting by Jean-François Millet completed in 1857. It depicts three peasant women gleaning a field of stray grains of wheat after the harvest, highlighting the dignity and hardship of rural laborers.
1800s.significance: A landmark of Realist painting, 'The Gleaners' is celebrated for its sympathetic portrayal of rural poverty and its social commentary on class and labor in 19th-century France.

1800s.title: Olympia
1800s.description: Olympia is a painting by French artist Édouard Manet depicting a nude woman reclining on a bed, attended by a maid. The work shocked audiences when first exhibited due to its frank portrayal of a nude courtesan and its modern, confrontational style.
1800s.significance: A pivotal work in the transition from Realism to Impressionism, 'Olympia' challenged academic conventions and social norms, and is considered a landmark in the history of modern art.

1800s.title: Impression, Sunrise
1800s.description: Impression, Sunrise is an 1872 painting by Claude Monet, first exhibited at the 1874 exhibition that would become known as the first Impressionist exhibition in Paris. The painting depicts the port of Le Havre at sunrise and is credited with inspiring the name of the Impressionist movement.
1800s.significance: This painting gave the Impressionist movement its name and is considered a seminal work in the development of modern art, exemplifying Monet's innovative approach to capturing light, atmosphere, and fleeting moments.

1800s.title: Starry Night Over the Rhône
1800s.description: Starry Night Over the Rhône is one of Vincent van Gogh's celebrated nocturne paintings, depicting a star-filled sky reflected in the waters of the Rhône River in Arles, France. Painted outdoors at night, the work captures the interplay of artificial gas lighting along the riverbank and the natural brilliance of the stars, exemplifying van Gogh's fascination with the night and his innovative use of color and brushwork.
1800s.significance: This painting is significant for its pioneering depiction of nocturnal light, its expressive use of color, and its role in van Gogh's exploration of the emotional and symbolic potential of the night sky. It is a key work in the development of modern art and a precursor to his later masterpiece, The Starry Night.

1800s.title: The Starry Night
1800s.description: The Starry Night is an oil-on-canvas painting by Dutch Post-Impressionist artist Vincent van Gogh, created in June 1889. It depicts a swirling night sky over a quiet town, as seen from the window of his asylum room at Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, with imaginative elements such as the cypress tree and a stylized village. The painting is celebrated for its expressive brushwork, vivid colors, and emotional intensity.
1800s.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York City, USA
1800s.significance: Regarded as one of the most iconic and influential paintings in Western art, The Starry Night exemplifies van Gogh's innovative use of color and brushwork, and has become a symbol of modern art's expressive potential.

1800s.title: Bal du moulin de la Galette
1800s.description: Bal du moulin de la Galette is a celebrated Impressionist painting by Pierre-Auguste Renoir, depicting a lively outdoor scene of working-class Parisians dancing and socializing at the Moulin de la Galette in Montmartre, Paris.
1800s.significance: One of the masterpieces of Impressionism, this painting captures the vibrant social life of late 19th-century Paris with luminous color, lively brushwork, and a sense of fleeting movement. It is renowned for its depiction of light and atmosphere, as well as its joyful, convivial subject matter.

1800s.title: The Thinker
1800s.description: The Thinker is a bronze sculpture by Auguste Rodin depicting a nude male figure of heroic size, seated on a rock with his chin resting on one hand as though deep in thought. Originally conceived as part of Rodin's monumental work 'The Gates of Hell', the figure has become an independent icon of intellectual activity and contemplation, symbolizing philosophy and the creative mind.
1800s.dimensions: Height: 186 cm (73 in); Width: 98 cm (38.5 in); Depth: 145 cm (57 in) [original monumental version]
1800s.significance: One of the most recognizable sculptures in the world, 'The Thinker' is celebrated for its expressive realism and psychological depth, embodying the spirit of modern sculpture and symbolizing human contemplation.

1800s.title: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
1800s.description: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte is Georges Seurat's most celebrated painting, created between 1884 and 1886. This monumental work exemplifies the pointillist technique, in which small, distinct dots of color are applied in patterns to form an image. The scene depicts Parisians relaxing in a suburban park on the banks of the River Seine, capturing the leisure activities of late 19th-century society. The painting is a cornerstone of the Neo-Impressionist movement.
1800s.current_location: Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois, USA
1800s.significance: A foundational work of Neo-Impressionism, this painting introduced the revolutionary technique of pointillism and profoundly influenced the direction of modern art. Its innovative approach to color and composition marks a pivotal moment in the transition from Impressionism to modernism.

1800s.title: A Burial at Ornans
1800s.description: A Burial at Ornans is a monumental painting by Gustave Courbet depicting a funeral in his hometown of Ornans, France. Painted between 1849 and 1850, it is a landmark of Realism, portraying ordinary townspeople with the gravity and scale traditionally reserved for historical or religious subjects. Its unidealized depiction of rural life and rejection of academic conventions caused a sensation at the 1850–51 Paris Salon.
1800s.significance: A pivotal work in the development of Realism, 'A Burial at Ornans' challenged academic norms by elevating a contemporary, provincial subject to the scale of history painting, profoundly influencing the course of modern art.

1800s.title: Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe
1800s.description: Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe (The Luncheon on the Grass) is a large oil painting by Édouard Manet, depicting a picnic scene with a nude woman and two fully dressed men in a rural setting. The work was highly controversial when first exhibited due to its bold subject matter and innovative style.
1800s.significance: A landmark in the history of modern art, Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe challenged academic conventions and paved the way for Impressionism with its radical composition, contemporary subject, and painterly technique.

1800s.title: Water Lilies (series)
1800s.description: Water Lilies is a series of approximately 250 oil paintings by French Impressionist Claude Monet (1840–1926). The paintings depict scenes from Monet's flower garden at his home in Giverny, focusing on the surface of the water, reflections, and the play of light. These works were the main focus of Monet's artistic production during the last three decades of his life, many painted while he suffered from cataracts.
1800s.current_location: Various museums worldwide, including the Musée de l'Orangerie (Paris), Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York), Art Institute of Chicago, and others.
1800s.dimensions: Varies; large panels at Musée de l'Orangerie: each approximately 200 cm × 600 cm (79 in × 236 in)
1800s.significance: A landmark series in Impressionism, Monet's Water Lilies transformed landscape painting and are celebrated for their innovative depiction of light, color, and perception. The series influenced later developments in abstraction and modern art.

1800s.title: Woman with a Parasol – Madame Monet and Her Son
1800s.description: Woman with a Parasol – Madame Monet and Her Son, sometimes known as The Stroll, is an oil-on-canvas painting by Claude Monet from 1875. The Impressionist work depicts his wife Camille Monet and their son Jean Monet during a stroll on a windy summer's day in Argenteuil, capturing a fleeting moment of light and movement.
1800s.current_location: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., USA
1800s.significance: A celebrated example of Impressionism, this painting showcases Monet's mastery in capturing light, atmosphere, and the spontaneity of modern life. It is notable for its loose brushwork and vibrant depiction of a personal, everyday scene.

1800s.title: Dance at Le Moulin de la Galette
1800s.description: Dance at Le Moulin de la Galette (French: Bal du moulin de la Galette) is a celebrated Impressionist painting by Pierre-Auguste Renoir depicting a lively Sunday afternoon dance at the Moulin de la Galette in the Montmartre district of Paris.
1800s.significance: A masterpiece of Impressionism, this painting captures the vibrant social life of late 19th-century Paris and is renowned for its luminous depiction of light, movement, and atmosphere.

1800s.title: The Ballet Class
1800s.description: The Ballet Class is an oil painting on canvas by French artist Edgar Degas, created between 1874 and 1876. The painting depicts a group of young ballet dancers at the end of a lesson, being instructed by ballet master Jules Perrot. Commissioned by the opera singer Jean-Baptiste Faure, the work exemplifies Degas's fascination with the world of dance, capturing both the elegance and the discipline of ballet. The composition is notable for its informal arrangement and the naturalistic depiction of movement and rehearsal.
1800s.significance: A celebrated example of Degas's exploration of modern life and movement, The Ballet Class is renowned for its innovative composition, psychological insight into its subjects, and its pivotal role in the development of Impressionist painting.

1800s.title: L’Absinthe
1800s.description: L'Absinthe, originally titled 'Dans un Café', is a painting by Edgar Degas depicting a woman and a man seated in a Parisian café, both appearing isolated and melancholic. The work explores themes of urban alienation and the social effects of absinthe consumption in late 19th-century Paris.
1800s.significance: A key work of Impressionism, 'L’Absinthe' is renowned for its candid portrayal of modern urban life and psychological depth, sparking controversy for its depiction of social isolation and the perceived moral decline associated with absinthe.

1800s.title: A Bar at the Folies-Bergère
1800s.description: A Bar at the Folies-Bergère is the last major painting by Édouard Manet, completed in 1882 and exhibited at the Paris Salon that year. The work depicts a barmaid standing before a mirror at the bustling Folies-Bergère nightclub in Paris, capturing the complexities of modern urban life and the ambiguities of perception and reality through its innovative composition and use of reflection.
1800s.significance: Regarded as a masterpiece of modern art, the painting is celebrated for its sophisticated play with perspective and reflection, its depiction of Parisian nightlife, and its exploration of themes such as urban alienation and the role of women in modern society. It marks a pivotal moment in the transition from Realism to Impressionism.

1800s.title: The Card Players
1800s.description: The Card Players is a renowned series of five oil paintings by French Post-Impressionist artist Paul Cézanne, created during his final period in the early 1890s. The paintings depict Provençal peasants immersed in a game of cards, varying in size, number of players, and setting. The series is celebrated for its monumental stillness, subtle psychological tension, and masterful composition, and is considered a precursor to modern art.
1800s.current_location: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, USA (one version); other versions are in the Musée d'Orsay (Paris), Courtauld Gallery (London), Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), and a private collection in Qatar.
1800s.dimensions: 97 cm × 130 cm (38 in × 51 in) (Metropolitan Museum version)
1800s.significance: Regarded as one of Cézanne's masterpieces and a pivotal work in the transition from 19th-century Impressionism to 20th-century Cubism, The Card Players series is celebrated for its innovative approach to composition, color, and form. It profoundly influenced later modern artists, including Picasso and Matisse.

1800s.title: Mont Sainte-Victoire
1800s.description: Mont Sainte-Victoire is one of a series of landscape paintings by Paul Cézanne, depicting the limestone mountain ridge near Aix-en-Provence in southern France. Cézanne returned to this motif repeatedly, exploring the changing light, color, and structure of the landscape, and developing a new approach to form and spatial relationships that would influence modern art.
1800s.current_location: Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, USA
1800s.significance: This painting is a seminal example of Cézanne's innovative approach to landscape, bridging Impressionism and Cubism, and is celebrated for its structural brushwork and influence on the development of modern art.

1800s.title: Bathers at Asnières
1800s.description: Bathers at Asnières is an 1884 oil on canvas painting by French artist Georges Seurat. It depicts a tranquil scene of working-class men and boys relaxing on the banks of the Seine in the Parisian suburb of Asnières. The composition is notable for its large scale, formal arrangement, and Seurat's innovative use of color and light, foreshadowing his later development of pointillism.
1800s.significance: This painting marks Seurat's first major work and is a key precursor to his development of pointillism. It is celebrated for its monumental scale, innovative color theory, and depiction of modern urban leisure, making it a foundational work in the transition from Impressionism to Post-Impressionism.

1800s.title: The Kiss
1800s.description: The Kiss is a marble sculpture by French artist Auguste Rodin, depicting a couple in a passionate embrace. Originally conceived as part of Rodin's monumental work 'The Gates of Hell', it became one of his most celebrated standalone pieces.
1800s.significance: Regarded as one of the most iconic sculptures of the late 19th century, 'The Kiss' exemplifies Rodin's mastery in capturing human emotion and sensuality, and has become a symbol of romantic love in Western art.

1800s.title: Sunflowers
1800s.description: Sunflowers is the title of two series of still life paintings by Vincent van Gogh. The best-known series was painted in Arles in 1888 and depicts vibrant yellow sunflowers in a vase. These works are celebrated for their bold color, expressive brushwork, and innovative use of the yellow palette, which Van Gogh associated with happiness and sunlight. The paintings were intended to decorate the room of Paul Gauguin, Van Gogh's friend and fellow artist, in the 'Yellow House' in Arles.
1800s.significance: One of Van Gogh's most iconic works, the Sunflowers series is renowned for its innovative use of color, emotional intensity, and influence on modern art. The paintings symbolize friendship and gratitude and are celebrated as masterpieces of Post-Impressionist still life.

1800s.title: Café Terrace at Night
1800s.description: Café Terrace at Night is an 1888 oil painting by the Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh. Depicting a brightly lit café in Arles, France, under a starry night sky, the work is celebrated for its vibrant color contrasts and innovative depiction of nocturnal light.
1800s.significance: This painting is notable for its pioneering use of color and light to capture the atmosphere of night without using black, and is one of Van Gogh's most beloved works. It marks an important moment in his exploration of nocturnal scenes and is considered a precursor to his later masterpiece, The Starry Night.

1800s.title: Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?
1800s.description: Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going? is a monumental painting by French Post-Impressionist artist Paul Gauguin, created in Tahiti. The work is a philosophical meditation on the human condition, exploring the cycle of life, existential questions, and spiritual themes through a symbolic narrative rendered in vivid colors and flattened forms.
1800s.current_location: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Massachusetts, USA
1800s.significance: Considered Gauguin's masterpiece, this painting encapsulates his search for meaning and his interest in symbolism, spirituality, and the exotic. It is a pivotal work in the development of modern art and reflects Gauguin's influence on later movements such as Symbolism and Primitivism.

1800s.title: Vision After the Sermon
1800s.description: Vision After the Sermon (Jacob Wrestling with the Angel) is an oil painting by French artist Paul Gauguin, completed in 1888. Painted in Pont-Aven, Brittany, it depicts Breton women in traditional dress witnessing a vision of Jacob wrestling with an angel after a sermon. The work is notable for its bold use of color, flat planes, and symbolic content, marking a departure from naturalism and a key moment in Gauguin's development of Synthetism.
1800s.significance: A seminal work in Gauguin's career, 'Vision After the Sermon' exemplifies the Synthetist style and symbolizes the artist's move toward abstraction and symbolism, influencing later modern art movements.

1800s.title: The Sleeping Gypsy
1800s.description: The Sleeping Gypsy is an 1897 oil on canvas painting by French Naïve artist Henri Rousseau. The work depicts a mysterious, dreamlike scene of a sleeping woman in North African dress, lying in a moonlit desert with a mandolin and a jar by her side, while a curious lion stands over her. The painting is celebrated for its vivid colors, imaginative subject matter, and the sense of stillness and enigma.
1800s.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York City, USA
1800s.significance: A quintessential example of Rousseau's dreamlike, imaginative style, 'The Sleeping Gypsy' is renowned for its poetic symbolism, mysterious atmosphere, and influence on later Surrealist artists.

1800s.title: Nocturne in Black and Gold – The Falling Rocket
1800s.description: Nocturne in Black and Gold – The Falling Rocket is a painting by James McNeill Whistler depicting a fireworks display over the Cremorne Gardens in London. The work is noted for its atmospheric abstraction and innovative use of color and form, exemplifying Whistler's interest in 'art for art's sake.'
1800s.current_location: Detroit Institute of Arts, Detroit, Michigan, USA
1800s.significance: A landmark of the Aesthetic Movement, the painting is renowned for its abstract qualities and was central to the famous Whistler v. Ruskin libel trial, which shaped debates about modern art and criticism.

1800s.title: Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1
1800s.description: Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1, commonly known as Whistler's Mother, is an oil painting by American-born artist James McNeill Whistler. The work depicts Whistler's mother, Anna McNeill Whistler, seated in profile against a grey wall. The painting is celebrated for its restrained composition, subtle tonal harmonies, and its exploration of the relationship between form and color. It is regarded as a masterpiece of portraiture and a key example of Whistler's interest in 'art for art's sake.'
1800s.significance: One of the most famous works by an American artist, 'Whistler's Mother' is an iconic image of motherhood and Victorian restraint. It exemplifies Whistler's aesthetic approach and has become a symbol of American art abroad.

1800s.title: The Gross Clinic
1800s.description: The Gross Clinic, also known as The Clinic of Dr. Gross, is a monumental oil painting by American artist Thomas Eakins. It depicts Dr. Samuel D. Gross, a prominent Philadelphia surgeon, performing surgery in front of his students at Jefferson Medical College. The work is celebrated for its dramatic realism, psychological intensity, and detailed depiction of 19th-century medical practice.
1800s.current_location: Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Philadelphia, USA (joint ownership)
1800s.significance: Regarded as one of the greatest American paintings of the 19th century, The Gross Clinic is celebrated for its unflinching realism, technical mastery, and its exploration of science, medicine, and education. The painting marks a pivotal moment in American art, reflecting Eakins's commitment to anatomical accuracy and the depiction of contemporary life.

1800s.title: American Gothic
1800s.description: American Gothic is a painting by Grant Wood depicting a farmer standing beside his daughter in front of a house with a distinctive Gothic window. The work is one of the most iconic images of 20th-century American art and is celebrated for its depiction of rural American life during the Great Depression.
1800s.current_location: Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, Illinois, USA
1800s.significance: A quintessential example of American Regionalism, 'American Gothic' has become an enduring symbol of the American Midwest and is noted for its detailed realism, ambiguous narrative, and cultural resonance.

1800s.title: The Oxbow
1800s.description: View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm, commonly known as The Oxbow, is a seminal American landscape painting by Thomas Cole, founder of the Hudson River School. The 1836 painting depicts a Romantic panorama of the Connecticut River Valley just after a thunderstorm. It has been interpreted as a confrontation between wilderness and civilization.
1800s.current_location: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City, USA
1800s.significance: A landmark of American landscape painting, The Oxbow is celebrated for its dramatic depiction of the tension between untamed wilderness and cultivated land, symbolizing the nation's expansion and the transformation of the American landscape.

1800s.title: Among the Sierra Nevada, California
1800s.description: Among the Sierra Nevada, California is an 1868 oil-on-canvas painting by German-American artist Albert Bierstadt. It depicts a dramatic and idealized landscape of the Sierra Nevada mountain range in California, with luminous light effects, a tranquil lake, and wildlife. Painted in Rome, the work was exhibited throughout Europe and helped promote the natural beauty of the American West.
1800s.current_location: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Washington, D.C., USA
1800s.significance: A masterpiece of American landscape painting, this work exemplifies the grandeur and idealized vision of the American West and played a role in shaping perceptions of the region during westward expansion.

1800s.title: Hokusai Manga
1800s.description: The Hokusai Manga is a collection of sketchbooks by the Japanese artist Katsushika Hokusai. Comprising thousands of drawings, the manga depict a wide array of subjects including landscapes, flora and fauna, daily life, people, and the supernatural, serving as both artistic inspiration and instructional material.
1800s.current_location: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, MA, USA
1800s.significance: A seminal work in Japanese art, the Hokusai Manga influenced generations of artists in Japan and abroad, offering a comprehensive visual encyclopedia of early 19th-century Japanese life and imagination. It played a key role in the development of manga and inspired Western artists during the Japonisme movement.

1800s.title: The Great Wave off Kanagawa
1800s.description: The Great Wave off Kanagawa is a woodblock print by the Japanese ukiyo-e artist Katsushika Hokusai, created in the late Edo period. It depicts three boats navigating a turbulent sea dominated by a towering, cresting wave, with Mount Fuji visible in the background. The dynamic composition and striking use of color have made it one of the most iconic images in Japanese art.
1800s.current_location: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York; multiple impressions in various collections worldwide
1800s.medium: Polychrome woodblock print (ink and color on paper)
1800s.significance: One of the most recognizable works of Japanese art, The Great Wave off Kanagawa exemplifies the ukiyo-e genre and has had a profound influence on Western art and popular culture.

1800s.title: Sudden Shower over Shin-Ōhashi Bridge
1800s.description: Sudden Shower over Shin-Ōhashi Bridge and Atake is a celebrated woodblock print by Japanese ukiyo-e artist Utagawa Hiroshige. Created in 1857 as part of the series One Hundred Famous Views of Edo, it depicts figures crossing the Shin-Ōhashi Bridge during a sudden rainstorm, capturing both the beauty and transience of everyday life in Edo (modern Tokyo).
1800s.significance: One of Hiroshige's most iconic works, this print is renowned for its dynamic depiction of weather and movement, influencing Western artists such as Vincent van Gogh and exemplifying the ukiyo-e genre's mastery of landscape and atmosphere.

1800s.title: Peonies and Butterfly
1800s.description: Peonies and Butterfly is a celebrated painting by Yun Shouping, one of the Six Masters of the early Qing period. The work exemplifies his mastery of the 'boneless' technique in flower painting, depicting lush peonies and a delicate butterfly with subtle washes of color and refined brushwork.
1800s.significance: This painting is a prime example of Yun Shouping's innovative approach to flower painting, showcasing the 'boneless' technique that influenced generations of Chinese artists. It reflects the refined aesthetics and technical mastery of Qing dynasty literati art.

1800s.title: Court Ladies Wearing Flowered Headdresses
1800s.year: 19th century (copy of a Tang dynasty original)
1800s.description: This painting depicts elegantly dressed court ladies of the Tang dynasty, adorned with elaborate flowered headdresses. The composition reflects the refined aesthetic and social customs of the Tang imperial court. The work is a 19th-century copy inspired by the style of Zhou Fang, a renowned painter of courtly women in 8th-century China.
1800s.current_location: Yale University Art Gallery, New Haven, Connecticut, USA
1800s.significance: This work exemplifies the enduring influence of Tang dynasty aesthetics and Zhou Fang's legacy in Chinese figure painting. It provides insight into historical fashion, beauty standards, and the cultural life of elite women in imperial China.

1800s.title: Landscape Scrolls (Qing dynasty)
1800s.description: Landscape scrolls from the Qing dynasty represent the continuation and transformation of traditional Chinese landscape painting. These works, often created by multiple artists, reflect the aesthetic values and technical mastery of the period, emphasizing harmony with nature, poetic atmosphere, and refined brushwork. Qing dynasty landscape scrolls often feature intricate depictions of mountains, rivers, and forests, blending realism with idealized natural scenes.
1800s.dimensions: Varies; typical scrolls range from 30–50 cm in height and several meters in length
1800s.significance: These scrolls exemplify the sophisticated landscape painting tradition of the Qing dynasty, showcasing both technical innovation and reverence for classical Chinese artistic ideals. They are important for understanding the evolution of Chinese painting and the cultural values of the Qing era.

1900_1945.title: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon
1900_1945.description: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon is a groundbreaking large oil painting by Spanish artist Pablo Picasso, completed in 1907. The work depicts five nude female figures in a brothel on Carrer d'Avinyó in Barcelona, rendered with angular, fractured forms and mask-like faces. The painting marks a radical break from traditional composition and perspective, incorporating influences from Iberian sculpture and African masks. It is widely considered a pivotal work in the development of Cubism and modern art.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: Regarded as one of the most influential paintings of the 20th century, 'Les Demoiselles d'Avignon' shattered conventional representation and paved the way for Cubism, revolutionizing modern art with its radical approach to form and perspective.

1900_1945.title: Composition VII
1900_1945.description: Composition VII is a monumental abstract oil painting created by Wassily Kandinsky in 1913. Widely regarded as one of his masterpieces, the work is a swirling, energetic composition that synthesizes themes of Resurrection, Judgment Day, the Flood, and the Garden of Eden. It exemplifies Kandinsky's pioneering role in the development of abstract art and his theories on the spiritual power of color and form.
1900_1945.current_location: Tretyakov Gallery, Moscow, Russia
1900_1945.significance: Considered one of the most important works of early abstract art, 'Composition VII' is a culmination of Kandinsky's exploration of non-representational painting and his theories on the emotional and spiritual resonance of color and form. It marks a turning point in modern art and influenced generations of abstract artists.

1900_1945.title: Fountain
1900_1945.description: Fountain is a readymade sculpture by Marcel Duchamp consisting of a porcelain urinal signed 'R. Mutt'. Submitted to the 1917 Society of Independent Artists exhibition in New York, it challenged traditional notions of art by presenting an ordinary object as an artwork.
1900_1945.current_location: Replica: Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, USA (original lost)
1900_1945.dimensions: 36 cm × 48 cm × 61 cm (14 in × 19 in × 24 in)
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of 20th-century art, 'Fountain' redefined the boundaries of art by introducing the concept of the 'readymade' and questioning the role of the artist and the art institution.

1900_1945.title: Guernica
1900_1945.description: Guernica is a monumental black-and-white oil painting by Pablo Picasso, created in response to the bombing of the Basque town of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War. The work powerfully depicts the tragedies of war and the suffering it inflicts upon individuals, particularly innocent civilians.
1900_1945.current_location: Museo Reina Sofía, Madrid, Spain
1900_1945.significance: Guernica is one of the most famous anti-war paintings in history, symbolizing the horrors of war and the suffering of innocent people. It has become an enduring symbol of peace and a powerful political statement.

1900_1945.title: The Persistence of Memory
1900_1945.description: The Persistence of Memory is a 1931 painting by Spanish artist Salvador Dalí and is one of the most iconic works of Surrealism. The painting features melting pocket watches draped over a dreamlike landscape, evoking themes of time, memory, and the subconscious. Its enigmatic imagery and technical precision have made it a symbol of Surrealist art and a frequent reference in popular culture.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York City, USA
1900_1945.significance: A quintessential work of Surrealism, 'The Persistence of Memory' is celebrated for its dreamlike imagery and exploration of the fluidity of time, and has become one of the most recognizable and influential paintings of the 20th century.

1900_1945.title: Broadway Boogie Woogie
1900_1945.description: Broadway Boogie Woogie is an abstract oil painting by Piet Mondrian, completed shortly after his move to New York City. The work reflects the city's grid structure and the rhythm of boogie-woogie music, using a vibrant arrangement of colored squares and rectangles.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: Considered one of Mondrian's masterpieces, this painting marks the culmination of his abstract style and his response to the energy of New York. It is celebrated for its innovative use of color, grid structure, and its synthesis of visual art and music.

1900_1945.title: The Red Studio
1900_1945.description: The Red Studio is an oil on canvas painting by French artist Henri Matisse, completed in 1911. The work depicts the artist’s studio in Issy-les-Moulineaux, filled with his own paintings, sculptures, and furniture, all unified by a vibrant red color that flattens the perspective and blurs the boundaries between objects and space.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of modern art, The Red Studio is celebrated for its radical use of color, spatial ambiguity, and its influence on abstraction. It exemplifies Matisse’s innovative approach to composition and color, and is considered a key work in the development of 20th-century painting.

1900_1945.title: Black Square
1900_1945.description: Black Square is a 1915 oil on canvas painting by Russian avant-garde artist Kazimir Malevich. It is considered the first and most iconic work of Suprematism, a movement focused on basic geometric forms and pure artistic feeling. Malevich created several versions of the painting, with the original debuting at the 0.10 Exhibition in Petrograd.
1900_1945.current_location: State Tretyakov Gallery, Moscow, Russia
1900_1945.significance: Regarded as a groundbreaking work in abstract art, Black Square marked the birth of Suprematism and represented a radical break from representational painting, influencing the development of modern art in the 20th century.

1900_1945.title: Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2
1900_1945.description: Nude Descending a Staircase, No. 2 is a 1912 painting by Marcel Duchamp that depicts a figure in motion, abstracted into a series of overlapping, fragmented forms. The work combines elements of Cubism and Futurism to convey movement and dynamism. It was initially rejected by the Cubists in Paris for being too Futurist, but later became a sensation and a subject of controversy at the 1913 Armory Show in New York, where it was both ridiculed and celebrated.
1900_1945.current_location: Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, USA
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of early 20th-century modernism, this painting challenged traditional representations of the human figure and movement, and played a pivotal role in the development of avant-garde art in both Europe and America.

1900_1945.title: The Elephants
1900_1945.description: The Elephants is a 1948 painting by Catalan surrealist Salvador Dalí, depicting two elephants with elongated, spindly legs carrying obelisks on their backs, set against a barren landscape. The work exemplifies Dalí's fascination with dream imagery and the juxtaposition of weight and weightlessness.
1900_1945.current_location: Private collection
1900_1945.significance: A quintessential example of Dalí's surrealist vision, 'The Elephants' explores themes of strength, fragility, and the subconscious. The painting is renowned for its dreamlike imagery and the symbolic use of elephants with impossibly long legs, reflecting Dalí's unique approach to surrealism.

1900_1945.title: Dance
1900_1945.description: Dance is a large-scale painting by Henri Matisse, depicting five nude figures holding hands and dancing in a circle against a vibrant landscape of green and blue. The work is celebrated for its bold use of color, simplified forms, and rhythmic composition, exemplifying Matisse's interest in expressive movement and the emotional power of color.
1900_1945.current_location: The Hermitage Museum, Saint Petersburg, Russia
1900_1945.significance: A masterpiece of early modernism, 'Dance' is one of Matisse's most iconic works, representing the height of Fauvist color and form. It is renowned for its radical simplification, dynamic composition, and its influence on 20th-century art.

1900_1945.title: Composition II in Red, Blue, and Yellow
1900_1945.description: Composition II in Red, Blue, and Yellow is a seminal painting by Dutch artist Piet Mondrian, exemplifying his mature style of geometric abstraction. The work features a grid of black lines with blocks of primary colors, reflecting Mondrian's pursuit of harmony and order through the reduction of form and color. It is a key example of the De Stijl movement's principles.
1900_1945.current_location: Stedelijk Museum, Amsterdam, Netherlands
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of abstract art, this painting embodies Mondrian's vision of pure abstraction and universal harmony, influencing generations of artists and designers.

1900_1945.title: Christina's World
1900_1945.description: Christina's World is a 1948 painting by American artist Andrew Wyeth, considered one of the most iconic American paintings of the 20th century. It depicts Christina Olson, a woman with a neuromuscular disorder, lying in a vast field and gazing toward a distant farmhouse in rural Maine. The work is celebrated for its emotional resonance, meticulous detail, and evocative realism.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of American Realism, 'Christina's World' is renowned for its poignant portrayal of isolation and perseverance, and for Wyeth's masterful technique. It has become an enduring symbol of the American spirit and rural life.

1900_1945.title: Metropolis
1900_1945.description: Metropolis is a powerful painting by German artist George Grosz, depicting the chaos, energy, and brutality of urban life in Berlin during World War I. The work is characterized by its dynamic composition, fragmented forms, and vivid colors, reflecting the anxiety and disillusionment of the era.
1900_1945.current_location: Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, Madrid, Spain
1900_1945.significance: An iconic example of German Expressionism, 'Metropolis' captures the psychological turmoil and social upheaval of wartime Berlin, exemplifying Grosz's critical view of modern urban society.

1900_1945.title: The City
1900_1945.description: The City is a large oil painting by French artist Fernand Léger, depicting the dynamic energy and modernity of urban life through bold colors, geometric forms, and overlapping planes. The work reflects Léger's fascination with the industrial city and the machine age.
1900_1945.current_location: Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, USA
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of early 20th-century modernism, 'The City' exemplifies Léger's innovative approach to Cubism and his celebration of urban and industrial themes, influencing later developments in abstract and modern art.

1900_1945.title: The Lovers
1900_1945.description: The Lovers is a surrealist painting by Belgian artist René Magritte, depicting two figures whose heads are shrouded in white cloth as they attempt to kiss. The work explores themes of love, mystery, and the unknowability of the other.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: A key example of Magritte's exploration of the tension between visible reality and hidden meaning, 'The Lovers' is celebrated for its enigmatic imagery and psychological depth, emblematic of Surrealist fascination with the unconscious.

1900_1945.title: The Son of Man
1900_1945.description: The Son of Man is a 1964 painting by the Belgian surrealist painter René Magritte. It depicts a man in an overcoat and bowler hat, his face obscured by a hovering green apple. The work is a quintessential example of Magritte's exploration of hidden realities and the tension between visible and concealed elements.
1900_1945.current_location: Private collection
1900_1945.significance: One of Magritte's most iconic works, 'The Son of Man' exemplifies the artist's fascination with mystery, concealment, and the unexpected. It has become a symbol of Surrealism and is widely referenced in popular culture.

1900_1945.title: Bird in Space
1900_1945.description: Bird in Space is a celebrated series of sculptures by Romanian artist Constantin Brâncuși, first created in 1923. The work abstracts the form of a bird in flight, reducing it to a sleek, elongated shape that suggests movement and spiritual ascent. Brâncuși produced the series in both marble and bronze over a period of two decades, with a total of sixteen known versions. The sculpture played a pivotal role in a landmark U.S. court case regarding the definition of art in 1926.
1900_1945.current_location: Philadelphia Museum of Art, Philadelphia, USA (one version); other versions in various collections
1900_1945.dimensions: 137.2 cm × 21.6 cm × 16.5 cm (54 in × 8.5 in × 6.5 in) [typical dimensions, varies by version]
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of modern sculpture, 'Bird in Space' exemplifies Brâncuși's pursuit of pure form and movement. It is renowned for its abstraction and for its role in a 1926 U.S. customs case that helped redefine the legal status of modern art.

1900_1945.title: Death and the Maiden
1900_1945.description: Death and the Maiden is an oil painting by Austrian artist Egon Schiele, depicting an embrace between a woman and a skeletal figure representing Death. The work reflects Schiele's preoccupation with mortality, love, and existential anxiety during World War I.
1900_1945.current_location: Österreichische Galerie Belvedere, Vienna, Austria
1900_1945.significance: This painting is considered one of Schiele's masterpieces, encapsulating themes of love, death, and the fragility of human existence. Created during a tumultuous period in the artist's life, it is a powerful example of early 20th-century Expressionism.

1900_1945.title: The Two Fridas
1900_1945.description: The Two Fridas is a large-scale oil painting by Mexican artist Frida Kahlo. It is a double self-portrait, depicting two seated versions of Kahlo holding hands and connected by a vein. One figure wears a European-style Victorian white dress, while the other wears a traditional Tehuana dress, symbolizing her dual heritage and emotional state following her divorce from Diego Rivera. The exposed hearts and the blood imagery reflect Kahlo's physical and emotional pain.
1900_1945.current_location: Museo de Arte Moderno, Mexico City, Mexico
1900_1945.significance: One of Frida Kahlo's most iconic works, The Two Fridas explores themes of identity, duality, and emotional suffering, and is celebrated for its powerful symbolism and autobiographical content.

1900_1945.title: Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird
1900_1945.description: Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird is a 1940 painting by Mexican artist Frida Kahlo. The self-portrait depicts Kahlo wearing a necklace of thorns, with a dead hummingbird hanging from it, flanked by a black cat and a monkey, and surrounded by lush foliage. The work reflects her physical and emotional pain following her divorce from Diego Rivera and the end of her affair with Nickolas Muray.
1900_1945.current_location: Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin, USA
1900_1945.significance: One of Kahlo's most iconic self-portraits, the painting is celebrated for its symbolic representation of pain, resilience, and identity, and is a key work in the canon of 20th-century Mexican art.

1900_1945.title: Suprematist Composition
1900_1945.description: Suprematist Composition (Blue Rectangle over the Red Beam) is a seminal abstract painting by Kazimir Malevich, exemplifying the radical geometric abstraction of the Suprematist movement. The work features dynamic arrangements of colored geometric forms, emphasizing pure artistic feeling over representation.
1900_1945.current_location: Private collection
1900_1945.significance: This painting is a landmark of early 20th-century abstract art and a key work of the Suprematist movement. It demonstrates Malevich's pioneering vision of non-objective art, focusing on basic geometric shapes and color to express spiritual purity and artistic autonomy.

1900_1945.title: Bauhaus Building
1900_1945.description: The Bauhaus Building in Dessau, designed by Walter Gropius, is a seminal work of modernist architecture. It served as the home of the Bauhaus school from 1926 to 1932 and is celebrated for its innovative use of glass, steel, and reinforced concrete, as well as its functional, asymmetrical design that embodied the Bauhaus principles of uniting art, craft, and technology.
1900_1945.current_location: Bauhaus Dessau Foundation, Dessau, Germany
1900_1945.significance: A landmark of 20th-century architecture, the Bauhaus Building exemplifies the ideals of the Bauhaus movement and has influenced generations of architects and designers worldwide.

1900_1945.title: Villa Savoye
1900_1945.description: Villa Savoye is a modernist villa located in Poissy, on the outskirts of Paris, France. Designed by Swiss-French architect Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret, it was constructed between 1928 and 1931. The villa exemplifies Le Corbusier's 'Five Points of Architecture' and is considered a seminal work of the International Style.
1900_1945.current_location: 82, Rue de Villiers, 78300 Poissy, Yvelines, France
1900_1945.dimensions: Approximately 400 m² (4,300 sq ft) floor area
1900_1945.significance: Villa Savoye is a masterpiece of modern architecture, embodying Le Corbusier's architectural principles and influencing generations of architects. It is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a key example of the International Style.

1900_1945.title: Weeping Woman
1900_1945.description: The Weeping Woman is an oil painting by Pablo Picasso, created in 1937 as part of a series depicting the motif of a woman in anguish. It is considered a continuation of the theme of suffering explored in Picasso's famous mural 'Guernica', with the weeping woman representing the pain and grief caused by war. The painting is renowned for its vivid colors, distorted forms, and emotional intensity.
1900_1945.current_location: Tate Modern, London, United Kingdom
1900_1945.significance: A powerful symbol of grief and suffering, 'Weeping Woman' is one of Picasso's most important works from his later Cubist period and a key anti-war statement, reflecting the horrors of the Spanish Civil War.

1900_1945.title: Der Blaue Reiter Almanac
1900_1945.description: The 'Der Blaue Reiter Almanac' was a seminal publication edited by Wassily Kandinsky and Franz Marc, serving as the theoretical and artistic manifesto of the Der Blaue Reiter group. The almanac featured essays, musical scores, and reproductions of artworks, reflecting the group's avant-garde ideas on abstraction, spirituality in art, and the synthesis of visual art and music. It played a crucial role in the development of Expressionism and modern art in early 20th-century Europe.
1900_1945.current_location: Various libraries and collections; notable copies at the Lenbachhaus, Munich, Germany
1900_1945.medium: Printed book (lithography and letterpress on paper)
1900_1945.significance: A foundational document of early 20th-century modernism, the Almanac articulated the theoretical underpinnings of Expressionism and influenced generations of artists and thinkers.

1900_1945.title: Improvisation 28 (second version)
1900_1945.description: Improvisation 28 (second version) is an abstract painting by Russian artist Wassily Kandinsky, created in 1912. It exemplifies Kandinsky's pioneering move toward pure abstraction, using expressive color, dynamic lines, and fragmented forms to evoke emotional and spiritual responses rather than depict recognizable subjects.
1900_1945.current_location: Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: A seminal work in the development of abstract art, this painting demonstrates Kandinsky's belief in the spiritual power of color and form, and his influential role in the Expressionist movement.

1900_1945.title: The Treachery of Images
1900_1945.description: The Treachery of Images is a 1929 painting by Belgian surrealist René Magritte. The work depicts a realistic image of a pipe with the caption 'Ceci n'est pas une pipe' ('This is not a pipe'), challenging the viewer's perceptions of representation and reality. It is one of the most iconic works of Surrealism.
1900_1945.current_location: Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Los Angeles, USA
1900_1945.significance: A seminal work in Surrealism, this painting explores the relationship between language, representation, and reality, famously illustrating the concept that images are not the things they depict.

1900_1945.title: Constructed Head No. 2
1900_1945.description: Constructed Head No. 2 is a pioneering example of Constructivist sculpture by Naum Gabo. The work demonstrates Gabo's innovative use of industrial materials and his interest in exploring space, form, and transparency through construction rather than traditional carving or modeling.
1900_1945.current_location: Tate Modern, London, UK
1900_1945.significance: This sculpture is a landmark of early Constructivism, exemplifying Gabo's radical approach to form and material. It influenced the development of modern sculpture by emphasizing construction and the use of industrial materials.

1900_1945.title: Composition with Yellow Patch
1900_1945.description: Composition with Yellow Patch is an abstract painting by Dutch artist Theo van Doesburg, a leading figure of the De Stijl movement. The work features geometric forms and a limited palette, emphasizing harmony and the reduction of visual elements to essentials.
1900_1945.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
1900_1945.significance: This painting exemplifies van Doesburg's commitment to the principles of De Stijl, focusing on abstraction, geometry, and primary colors. It played a key role in the development of modern abstract art.

1900_1945.title: Abstract Speed + Sound
1900_1945.description: Abstract Speed + Sound (Velocità astratta + rumore) is a painting by Italian Futurist artist Giacomo Balla, part of a series exploring the dynamism of movement and the sensation of speed, integral to the Futurist fascination with modern technology and progress.
1900_1945.current_location: Peggy Guggenheim Collection, Venice, Italy
1900_1945.significance: A key work of Italian Futurism, this painting exemplifies Balla's innovative approach to representing motion, speed, and sound, reflecting the movement's embrace of modernity and technological advancement.

1900_1945.title: Unique Forms of Continuity in Space
1900_1945.description: Unique Forms of Continuity in Space is a seminal Futurist sculpture by Umberto Boccioni, created in 1913. The work captures the dynamic movement and fluidity of a striding human figure, embodying the Futurist fascination with speed, technology, and modernity. Its abstracted, aerodynamic forms convey a sense of motion and transformation.
1900_1945.current_location: Museo del Novecento, Milan, Italy (bronze cast); original plaster at Museu de Arte Contemporânea da Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil
1900_1945.significance: A masterpiece of Futurist sculpture, it is celebrated for its innovative depiction of movement and the human form, and has become an icon of early 20th-century modernism. The sculpture is featured on the Italian 20 cent euro coin.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Number 1A
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Number 1A is a large-scale abstract expressionist painting by Jackson Pollock, exemplifying his signature drip technique and energetic, gestural style.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Oil and enamel paint on canvas
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of Abstract Expressionism, Number 1A demonstrates Pollock's innovative drip painting technique and his move toward all-over composition, influencing generations of artists.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Campbell's Soup Cans
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Campbell's Soup Cans is a series of 32 paintings produced by American artist Andy Warhol. Each canvas depicts a different variety of Campbell's soup, rendered in a style that mimics commercial printing. The series is a landmark of the Pop Art movement, challenging traditional distinctions between fine art and mass-produced imagery.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: The Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Synthetic polymer paint on canvas
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Each canvas: 51 cm × 41 cm (20 in × 16 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A seminal work of Pop Art, 'Campbell's Soup Cans' redefined the boundaries of art by elevating everyday commercial imagery to the status of fine art and critiquing consumer culture.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Blue Poles
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Blue Poles, also known as Number 11, 1952, is a landmark abstract expressionist painting by American artist Jackson Pollock. The work is renowned for its dynamic composition, featuring bold blue vertical lines over a complex web of dripped and splattered paint. Its acquisition by the National Gallery of Australia in 1973 was highly controversial and marked a turning point in the recognition of modern American art internationally.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: National Gallery of Australia, Canberra
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Enamel and aluminum paint with glass on canvas
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Considered one of Pollock's masterpieces and a key example of Abstract Expressionism, 'Blue Poles' is notable for its scale, innovative technique, and its role in establishing the international reputation of postwar American art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Untitled (Portrait of Ross in L.A.)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: "Untitled" (Portrait of Ross in L.A.) is a conceptual installation by Cuban-American artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres. The work consists of a pile of individually wrapped candies, ideally weighing 175 pounds (79 kg), which visitors are invited to take and consume. The diminishing pile alludes to the gradual loss of Gonzalez-Torres's partner, Ross Laycock, to AIDS, and the replenishment of the pile by museum staff symbolizes care and remembrance. The work is both participatory and ephemeral, challenging traditional notions of permanence in art.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Art Institute of Chicago, Chicago, United States
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Individually wrapped candies, endless supply
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Ideal weight: 175 lb (79 kg); dimensions variable
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of participatory and conceptual art, the work is a poignant meditation on love, loss, and the AIDS crisis, inviting viewers to engage physically and emotionally with the memory of the artist's partner.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living is a seminal work by Damien Hirst, consisting of a tiger shark preserved in formaldehyde within a large glass vitrine. Commissioned by art collector Charles Saatchi, the piece confronts viewers with the reality of death and the boundaries between art and life.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, USA (on loan from the Steven A. Cohen collection)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Tiger shark, glass, steel, 5% formaldehyde solution
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of contemporary art, this work epitomizes the shock tactics and conceptual approach of the Young British Artists, provoking debate about mortality, preservation, and the definition of art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Balloon Dog
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Balloon Dog is a series of monumental sculptures by American artist Jeff Koons, created as part of his 'Celebration' series. The sculptures resemble twisted balloon animals, rendered in highly polished stainless steel with transparent color coatings. Five unique versions exist, each in a different color: blue, magenta, yellow, orange, and red.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Various (individual pieces in private collections and museums; Balloon Dog (Orange) was sold at Christie's, New York; Balloon Dog (Blue) at The Broad, Los Angeles)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Mirror-polished stainless steel with transparent color coating
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Balloon Dog is one of Jeff Koons's most iconic works, exemplifying his use of industrial materials and playful, familiar forms to challenge notions of high and low art. The sculptures have become symbols of contemporary art's engagement with consumer culture and have achieved record-breaking auction prices.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Dinner Party
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Dinner Party is a landmark installation artwork by American feminist artist Judy Chicago. The work consists of a large, triangular table with 39 elaborate place settings, each commemorating an important woman from history or mythology. The settings include intricately decorated ceramic plates and embroidered runners, with the names of 999 additional women inscribed on the floor below. The piece is a celebration of women's achievements and a critique of their historical marginalization.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Porcelain, textile (embroidered runners), mixed media
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Overall: 1463 cm × 1463 cm × 76.2 cm (48 ft × 48 ft × 30 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Widely regarded as a milestone of feminist art, 'The Dinner Party' brought attention to the achievements of women throughout history and challenged the male-dominated art historical canon. Its collaborative creation and monumental scale helped redefine the possibilities of installation art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Spiral Jetty
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Spiral Jetty is a monumental earthwork and iconic piece of land art constructed by American artist Robert Smithson in April 1970. Built on the northeastern shore of the Great Salt Lake near Rozel Point in Utah, the work consists of a 1,500-foot-long (460 m), 15-foot-wide (4.6 m) counterclockwise spiral made from mud, salt crystals, basalt rocks, and earth. The sculpture interacts with the changing water levels and salinity of the lake, often submerging and re-emerging over time. Smithson documented the construction in a 32-minute color film, also titled Spiral Jetty.
