Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Rozel Point, Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.creation_location: Rozel Point, Great Salt Lake, Utah, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Basalt rock, earth, salt crystals, mud
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: 460 m (1,500 ft) long; 4.6 m (15 ft) wide
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of the Land Art movement, Spiral Jetty is celebrated for its integration of art and landscape, its engagement with entropy and natural processes, and its influence on environmental and conceptual art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Girl with Balloon
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Girl with Balloon is a series of stencil murals created by the anonymous street artist Banksy, first appearing in London in 2002. The image depicts a young girl reaching out toward a red, heart-shaped balloon being carried away by the wind. Originally painted on the walls under Waterloo Bridge and in Shoreditch, the murals have become one of Banksy's most iconic images and have been reproduced in prints and other media.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Spray paint and stencil on wall
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable (site-specific mural); original Shoreditch mural approx. 60 cm × 90 cm (24 in × 35 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: One of the most recognizable works of contemporary street art, 'Girl with Balloon' has become a symbol of hope and lost innocence. Its imagery and message have been widely reproduced and referenced in popular culture. The work also gained notoriety when a print version partially shredded itself at auction in 2018.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Weather Project
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Weather Project is a large-scale installation by Icelandic–Danish artist Olafur Eliasson, which filled the Turbine Hall of Tate Modern in London. The installation simulated the experience of a vast indoor sun and mist-filled atmosphere, using light, mirrors, and haze to immerse visitors in an artificial environment that encouraged reflection on nature and perception.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Monofrequency lights, haze machines, mirrors, aluminum, scaffolding
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Approximately 26.7 m × 22.3 m × 155.4 m (88 ft × 73 ft × 510 ft) (entire Turbine Hall)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark in immersive installation art, The Weather Project transformed the museum experience and engaged the public in questions about perception, environment, and collective experience. It is considered one of the most influential works of early 21st-century art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: My Bed
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: My Bed is an installation artwork by Tracey Emin, consisting of her own unmade bed surrounded by personal items such as empty bottles, cigarette butts, condoms, and underwear. The piece presents an intimate snapshot of the artist's life during a period of emotional turmoil, challenging traditional boundaries between art and life. First exhibited at the Tate Gallery in 1999 as a Turner Prize nominee, it sparked widespread debate about the nature of contemporary art.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Tate Britain, London, UK
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Bed, mattress, linens, pillows, personal objects (found objects)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A seminal work of the Young British Artists movement, 'My Bed' is renowned for its raw autobiographical content and for challenging conventions of sculpture and installation art. It has become an iconic example of confessional art and provoked ongoing discussion about the boundaries of art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Rabbit
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Rabbit is a stainless steel sculpture by American artist Jeff Koons, created in 1986. The work is a highly polished, inflatable toy-like figure of a rabbit, rendered in reflective metal. It is considered one of the most iconic and influential works of contemporary art, exemplifying Koons's interest in consumer culture, mass production, and the transformation of everyday objects into high art.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: The Broad Art Foundation, Los Angeles, California, USA (one edition); other editions in private collections
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Stainless steel
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Regarded as a landmark of contemporary art, 'Rabbit' is celebrated for its playful yet enigmatic form and its commentary on consumerism and artifice. In 2019, one edition of the sculpture set a record for the most expensive work by a living artist sold at auction.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Sunflower Seeds
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Sunflower Seeds is a large-scale installation by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, consisting of over 100 million hand-crafted porcelain sunflower seed replicas. Each seed was individually sculpted and painted by artisans in Jingdezhen, China, referencing both traditional craftsmanship and mass production.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Tate Modern, London, UK (original installation); individual seeds are now dispersed in collections worldwide
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Hand-painted porcelain
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Originally approximately 1,000 square meters (10 cm deep), comprising over 100 million seeds
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: This work explores themes of mass production, individuality, Chinese cultural history, and political commentary. It is celebrated for its scale, craftsmanship, and its reflection on collective versus individual identity.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Dropping a Han Dynasty Urn
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Dropping a Han Dynasty Urn is a photographic triptych by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, created in 1995. The work consists of three black-and-white photographs, each measuring 148 by 121 cm, that sequentially document Ai holding, dropping, and standing over the shattered remains of a Han dynasty (206 BCE–220 CE) urn, approximately 2,000 years old. The act is both a literal and symbolic gesture, challenging notions of cultural value, history, and authority.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Private collection
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Gelatin silver print (photographic triptych)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Each panel: 148 cm × 121 cm (58.3 in × 47.6 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark work in contemporary Chinese art, the piece critiques the relationship between cultural heritage and modernity, questioning the value systems that govern art, history, and authority. It is emblematic of Ai Weiwei's provocative approach and has become an iconic statement on destruction and transformation.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Infinity Mirror Rooms
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Infinity Mirror Rooms are a series of immersive installation artworks by Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama. Using mirrors, lights, and various objects, Kusama creates environments that produce the illusion of infinite space, enveloping viewers in a kaleidoscopic and disorienting experience. The first of these rooms, 'Phalli's Field' (1965), marked a breakthrough in Kusama's practice and has since inspired numerous variations and exhibitions worldwide.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Various museums and collections worldwide; notable examples at The Broad, Los Angeles, and Tate Modern, London
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Mirrors, lights, mixed media installation
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable; typically room-sized installations
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Kusama's Infinity Mirror Rooms are celebrated for their pioneering use of immersive environments and their profound influence on installation art. They invite viewers to experience a sense of boundlessness and self-obliteration, central themes in Kusama's work.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Pumpkin
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Yayoi Kusama's 'Pumpkin' is a large-scale sculpture featuring her signature motif of a bright yellow pumpkin covered in black polka dots. The work exemplifies Kusama's fascination with repetition, organic forms, and her ongoing exploration of the pumpkin as a symbol of comfort and fantasy. The sculpture is celebrated for its whimsical yet meditative presence and its vibrant, immersive visual impact.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Naoshima Island, Benesse Art Site, Kagawa Prefecture, Japan
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Painted fiberglass-reinforced plastic
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Height: 2.5 m (8.2 ft); Width: 2.0 m (6.6 ft); Depth: 2.0 m (6.6 ft)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A defining work of Kusama's career, 'Pumpkin' has become an iconic symbol of contemporary Japanese art and is internationally recognized for its playful yet profound engagement with themes of nature, repetition, and personal obsession.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Untitled Film Stills
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Untitled Film Stills is a series of 70 black-and-white photographs by American artist Cindy Sherman, created between 1977 and 1980. In these staged self-portraits, Sherman adopts various female roles inspired by 1950s and 1960s Hollywood, film noir, B-movies, and European art-house films, exploring themes of identity, gender, and representation.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, NY, USA (major holdings); various works in private and public collections
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Gelatin silver print
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Each photograph approx. 20.3 × 25.4 cm (8 × 10 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark in feminist and conceptual art, the series challenged traditional representations of women in media and established Sherman as a leading figure in contemporary art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Guerrilla Girls Posters
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Guerrilla Girls Posters are a series of provocative, text- and image-based works created by the anonymous feminist collective Guerrilla Girls. Founded in New York City in 1985, the group uses posters, billboards, and other public interventions to expose gender and racial inequality in the art world and beyond. Their posters, often wheat-pasted in public spaces or distributed at events, employ humor, bold graphics, and statistics to challenge discrimination and corruption in cultural institutions. The members conceal their identities with gorilla masks and adopt pseudonyms of deceased women artists and writers, emphasizing collective action over individual fame.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Offset lithograph and screenprint on paper
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable (typically around 43 x 56 cm / 17 x 22 in per poster)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.style: Feminist art, Activist art, Conceptual art
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: The Guerrilla Girls Posters are iconic works of activist art that have brought widespread attention to systemic sexism and racism in the art world. Their bold, accessible visual language and use of public space have inspired generations of artists and activists, making them a touchstone of late 20th-century and contemporary feminist art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: One and Three Chairs
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: One and Three Chairs is a seminal conceptual artwork by Joseph Kosuth, created in 1965. The installation consists of a physical chair, a life-size photograph of that chair as installed in the space, and an enlarged dictionary definition of the word 'chair.' By juxtaposing the object, its image, and its linguistic description, Kosuth explores the relationship between language, representation, and reality. The work is re-created for each exhibition, with the chair and photograph changing according to the installation context.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Wooden chair, gelatin silver print, photographic enlargement of text on paper
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Chair: variable; Photograph and text panel: each approx. 91.4 × 61 cm (36 × 24 in)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of conceptual art, 'One and Three Chairs' challenges traditional notions of art by foregrounding the idea over the object, and interrogates how meaning is constructed through language, image, and material reality.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: I Like America and America Likes Me
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: I Like America and America Likes Me is a seminal performance artwork by German artist Joseph Beuys. For three days in May 1974, Beuys lived in a New York gallery space with a wild coyote, interacting with the animal as part of a ritualistic and symbolic action exploring themes of healing, cultural identity, and the relationship between humans and nature.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.creation_location: René Block Gallery, New York City, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Performance; documented by photographs and video
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Duration: 3 days (May 23–25, 1974)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: This performance is considered one of Beuys's most influential works, symbolizing his ideas about social sculpture and the potential for art to heal cultural wounds. The interaction with the coyote referenced Native American symbolism and critiqued American society, while also addressing themes of exile, reconciliation, and the artist's complex relationship with the United States.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: 7000 Oaks
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: 7000 Oaks – City Forestation Instead of City Administration is a pioneering work of social sculpture and land art by German artist Joseph Beuys. Initiated at documenta 7 in 1982, the project involved the planting of 7,000 oak trees, each paired with a basalt stone, throughout the city of Kassel, Germany, as an ecological and social intervention.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Kassel, Germany (public spaces throughout the city)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Live oak trees and basalt stones (land art, social sculpture)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Citywide installation; each tree paired with a basalt stone approximately 1.2 m tall
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.style: Land Art, Social Sculpture, Conceptual Art
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark in environmental and participatory art, 7000 Oaks redefined the boundaries of sculpture and art's role in society, emphasizing ecological responsibility and community involvement.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Piss Christ
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Piss Christ is a 1987 photograph by American artist Andres Serrano. The image depicts a small plastic crucifix submerged in a glass tank of the artist's urine. The work is part of Serrano's series exploring bodily fluids and religious iconography, provoking debate about blasphemy, freedom of expression, and the role of public funding in the arts.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Private collection
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Cibachrome print mounted on Plexiglas
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A highly controversial work that sparked national debate in the United States over public funding for the arts, censorship, and the boundaries of artistic expression. It is considered a seminal piece in late 20th-century art discourse.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Gates
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Gates was a site-specific installation by Christo and Jeanne-Claude, consisting of 7,503 free-standing saffron-colored fabric panels suspended from steel frames, installed along 23 miles (37 km) of pathways in Central Park, New York City. The project transformed the park's winter landscape for 16 days, inviting visitors to experience the environment in a new way.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Steel, vinyl, and nylon fabric
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Each gate: 4.87 m (16 ft) tall; total installation: 23 miles (37 km) of pathways
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark example of large-scale environmental installation art, The Gates engaged the public and transformed a major urban park, highlighting the collaborative vision of Christo and Jeanne-Claude and their ability to realize ambitious temporary projects.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Sky Mirror
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Sky Mirror is a large public sculpture by Anish Kapoor, commissioned by the Nottingham Playhouse and installed outside the theatre in Wellington Circus, Nottingham, England. The work consists of a 6-metre-wide (20 ft) concave dish of polished stainless steel, weighing 10 tonnes, and angled upwards to reflect the sky and its surroundings, creating a dynamic visual experience that changes with the environment.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Outside Nottingham Playhouse, Wellington Circus, Nottingham, England
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Polished stainless steel
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: 6 m (20 ft) diameter; 3 m (10 ft) high; 10 tonnes
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Sky Mirror is a landmark example of Kapoor's exploration of perception, reflection, and space. It transforms its environment by reflecting the sky and surroundings, engaging viewers in a constantly shifting visual dialogue. The work is celebrated for its technical achievement and its impact on public art in the UK.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Cloud Gate
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Cloud Gate is a public sculpture by Indian-born British artist Anish Kapoor, serving as the centerpiece of Millennium Park in Chicago. Nicknamed "The Bean" for its distinctive, elliptical shape, the sculpture is composed of 168 stainless steel plates seamlessly welded together and highly polished to reflect the city's skyline and visitors. Its interactive, mirror-like surface invites public engagement and has become an iconic symbol of Chicago.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Millennium Park, Chicago, Illinois, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Stainless steel
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Cloud Gate is one of the most recognizable public sculptures in the United States, celebrated for its innovative design, interactive qualities, and its role as a cultural landmark and gathering place in Chicago.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: No Woman No Cry
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: "No Woman No Cry" is a large mixed-media painting by British artist Chris Ofili. The work is a portrait of a Black woman, Doreen Lawrence, the mother of murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence, and incorporates layers of paint, resin, glitter, map pins, and elephant dung. Each of the woman's tears contains a small image relating to Stephen Lawrence's life and legacy.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Tate Britain, London, UK
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Acrylic, oil, resin, glitter, map pins, and elephant dung on canvas
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark of contemporary British art, the painting is celebrated for its innovative materials and poignant tribute to Doreen Lawrence, highlighting issues of race, grief, and resilience in the UK.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: African Masks
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: African masks are traditional objects made and used by various cultures across Sub-Saharan Africa, often as part of religious and social ceremonies. These masks are typically carved from wood and may be adorned with paint, beads, shells, or metal. They serve as powerful spiritual symbols, mediating between the human and spirit worlds, and are central to rituals, dances, and storytelling. In the 20th century, African masks became influential in Western art, notably inspiring artists such as Picasso and Matisse, which has led to ongoing discourse about cultural appropriation.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Africa
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Carved wood, pigment, raffia, beads, shells, and metal
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Varies; typically 25–60 cm (10–24 in) in height
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: African masks are among the most recognized and influential forms of African art, playing vital roles in ritual and social contexts and profoundly impacting modern Western art through appropriation and reinterpretation.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Video Corridor
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Video Corridor is an influential installation by Bruce Nauman that uses video technology and architectural space to create a disorienting and psychologically charged experience for viewers. The work consists of a narrow corridor with a video monitor at one end, displaying live or recorded footage of the viewer as they walk through the space, challenging perceptions of surveillance, presence, and self-awareness.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Tate Modern, London, UK (various versions exist in major museum collections)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Corridor structure, closed-circuit video cameras, monitors, wood, and electronic equipment
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable dimensions (typically corridor approx. 4.8 m × 1.2 m × 2.4 m / 16 ft × 4 ft × 8 ft)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A pioneering work in video and installation art, 'Video Corridor' explores themes of surveillance, perception, and the relationship between viewer and artwork, and is considered a landmark in the development of interactive and experiential art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: House
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: House was a large-scale public sculpture by British artist Rachel Whiteread. The work consisted of a concrete cast of the interior of a Victorian terraced house at 193 Grove Road, East London, capturing the negative space of the building before its demolition. The sculpture evoked themes of memory, absence, and the traces of domestic life, and became a landmark of British contemporary art before its controversial demolition in 1994.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Concrete cast of a Victorian terraced house
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Approx. 8.5 m × 7.7 m × 5.5 m (28 ft × 25 ft × 18 ft)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A seminal work in contemporary sculpture, 'House' won the Turner Prize and sparked public debate about memory, loss, and the role of art in public space. It is considered a landmark in Rachel Whiteread's career and British art of the 1990s.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: For the Love of God
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: For the Love of God is a sculpture by British artist Damien Hirst, created in 2007. The work consists of a platinum cast of an 18th-century human skull encrusted with 8,601 flawless diamonds, including a prominent pear-shaped pink diamond set in the forehead, known as the Skull Star Diamond. The original human teeth are set into the skull. The piece serves as a contemporary memento mori, confronting themes of mortality, value, and the relationship between art and commerce.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: White Cube Gallery, London, UK (private collection; exhibited internationally)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Platinum, 8,601 diamonds, human teeth
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A provocative and iconic work of contemporary art, 'For the Love of God' explores themes of death, luxury, and the commodification of art. It is notable for its extravagant use of precious materials and for generating widespread debate about the value and meaning of art in the 21st century.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Visitors
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Visitors is a nine-channel video installation by Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson. Filmed at Rokeby Farm in upstate New York, the work features musicians performing simultaneously in different rooms of a historic mansion, creating an immersive and emotionally resonant musical experience.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Various international museums and galleries; original owned by Migros Museum für Gegenwartskunst, Zurich, Switzerland
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.creation_location: Rokeby Farm, Barrytown, New York, USA
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Nine-channel high-definition video and audio installation
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable installation dimensions
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Widely regarded as one of the most important video installations of the 21st century, 'The Visitors' explores themes of collaboration, isolation, and the emotional power of music through a unique multi-sensory experience.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Artist Is Present
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: The Artist Is Present is a performance art piece by Marina Abramović, staged at the Museum of Modern Art in New York from March to May 2010. During the performance, Abramović sat silently at a table for over 700 hours, inviting museum visitors to sit in front of her and engage in a silent exchange of gazes. The work explored themes of presence, endurance, vulnerability, and the relationship between artist and audience.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Museum of Modern Art, New York, USA (performance documentation and related materials)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Performance art (live performance, video documentation, photographs, installation)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable (performance space and duration: 736.5 hours over 3 months)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: A landmark in performance art, 'The Artist Is Present' is celebrated for its exploration of endurance, presence, and the direct connection between artist and audience. It is widely regarded as a defining work in Abramović's career and a pivotal moment in the history of contemporary art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Cut Piece
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Cut Piece is a pioneering performance art piece by Yoko Ono, first performed on July 20, 1964, at the Yamaichi Concert Hall in Kyoto, Japan. In this work, Ono sat motionless on stage and invited audience members to come up and cut pieces of her clothing off with scissors, challenging conventions of art, gender, and spectatorship.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Performance art (live action, artist's clothing, scissors, audience participation)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable (dependent on performance and space)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Regarded as a landmark in performance and feminist art, 'Cut Piece' confronts issues of vulnerability, objectification, and the role of the audience, and is considered one of the earliest examples of participatory art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Shoot
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: "Shoot" is a seminal performance artwork by Chris Burden in which the artist arranged to have himself shot in the left arm with a .22 rifle by an assistant at close range. The performance took place in front of a small audience in a gallery in Santa Ana, California, and was documented by video and photography. The work is a provocative exploration of risk, violence, and the boundaries of art.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Performance (documented by video and photography)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable (performance; video documentation exists)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Regarded as a landmark in performance art, 'Shoot' challenged the limits of the body, the role of the artist, and the audience's complicity, provoking debate about violence, risk, and the nature of art.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: Huang Yong Ping Installations
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Huang Yong Ping was a Chinese-French contemporary artist, recognized for his large-scale installations that merged Eastern and Western philosophies, critiqued political and cultural systems, and explored themes of chance, history, and power. His works from the 1990s often incorporated readymade objects, animal motifs, and references to both Chinese and Western traditions, challenging viewers to reconsider cultural boundaries and authority.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Mixed media installation (varied materials including wood, metal, textiles, found objects)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Variable (site-specific installations)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: Huang Yong Ping's installations from the 1990s are pivotal in the global contemporary art scene, exemplifying cross-cultural dialogue and critical engagement with history, politics, and tradition. He was a leading figure in the Chinese avant-garde and a founder of the Xiamen Dada movement, influencing generations of artists worldwide.

Post_1945_and_Contemporary.title: The Physical Impossibility (restoration)
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.description: Rosie is a preserved great white shark located at Crystal World Exhibition Centre in Devon Meadows, Australia. Originally displayed in a glass tank of formaldehyde at Wildlife Wonderland in Bass, Victoria, the shark became an urban exploration destination after the park's closure in 2012. Rosie was later recovered and transferred to the Crystal World Exhibition Centre, where she is undergoing restoration. This work echoes Damien Hirst's iconic 1991 installation 'The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living,' which used a similar preserved shark.
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.current_location: Crystal World Exhibition Centre, Devon Meadows, Victoria, Australia
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.medium: Preserved great white shark in glass tank with formaldehyde
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.dimensions: Approx. 5 m (16 ft) in length (shark); tank dimensions variable
Post_1945_and_Contemporary.significance: This artwork is a notable example of contemporary installation art, referencing Damien Hirst's influential use of preserved animals to explore themes of mortality and perception. 'Rosie' has become a cultural phenomenon in Australia and highlights the intersection of art, science, and popular curiosity.
